class="clean-btn tocCollapsibleButton_dfMV">On this page</button></div><div class="theme-doc-markdown markdown"><header><h1>Feature Engineering</h1></header>
<p>Feature Engineering in the <strong>Lorentzian Classification</strong> indicator involves selecting, transforming, and curating meaningful data inputs before they feed into the machine learning model. Well-chosen features help the model recognize complex market patterns, reduce noise, and ultimately produce more robust trading signals. Conversely, poorly chosen or overly redundant features can lead to overfitting, slow computations, or misleading results.</p>

class="section_G6Eg"><h4><span class="sectionIcon_VFN2">ðŸŽ¯</span>Purpose</h4><p>RSI is a momentum oscillator that measures the speed and magnitude of recent price changes. It excels at identifying overbought and oversold conditions while maintaining consistent normalization within the Lorentzian Classification framework.</p></div><div class="section_G6Eg"><h4><span class="sectionIcon_VFN2">ðŸ› ï¸</span>How it Works</h4><p>RSI computes the ratio of average gains to losses over a specified period. The indicator oscillates between 0-100, with readings above 70 signaling overbought conditions and below 30 indicating oversold levels.</p></div><div class="section_G6Eg"><h4><span class="sectionIcon_VFN2">ðŸ’«</span>Impact</h4><p>Primary Strengths:
- Identifies potential price reversals
- Measures momentum strength
- Reveals bullish/bearish divergences
- Provides normalized readings</p></div><div class="section_G6Eg"><h4><span class="sectionIcon_VFN2">âš™ï¸</span>Parameters</h4><p>Each feature's behavior is controlled by two key parameters working in tandem: <strong>Parameter A</strong> (<!-- -->0<!-- -->) functions as the primary calculation period, similar to how RSI uses a lookback window to analyze price movements, while<!-- --> <strong>Parameter B</strong> (<!-- -->0<!-- -->) complements this by providing smoothing adjustments. Together, these parameters create a flexible framework for customizing your analysis.</p><p>Note: For custom source configurations, these parameters become inactive - adjust settings directly in your custom indicator instead.</p></div><div class="section_G6Eg"><h4><span class="sectionIcon_VFN2">âœ…</span>Enable</h4><p>Disabled</p><p>When the feature is enabled, it actively contributes to the multi-dimensional computation of scores. Unchecking the enable button removes this feature from the calculation, so its data will no longer factor into your overall signal evaluation.</p></div><div class="section_G6Eg"><h4><span class="sectionIcon_VFN2">ðŸ’¡</span>Recommendations</h4><ul><li>1. Start with standard 14-period setting</li><li>2. Adjust periods based on volatility</li><li>3. Monitor divergences with price</li><li>4. Combine with trend indicators</li><li>5. Use support/resistance levels</li><li>6. Watch extreme readings (>70/<30)</li><li>7. Consider market context</li><li>8. Validate signals across timeframes</li></ul></div></div></div></div></div>
<h2 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="why-feature-engineering-matters">Why Feature Engineering Matters<a href="#why-feature-engineering-matters" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to Why Feature Engineering Matters" title="Direct link to Why Feature Engineering Matters">â€‹</a></h2>
<p><strong>Enhanced Predictive Power</strong>
Financial data can be noisy and non-stationary. Meaningful transformations often reveal underlying signals the model might otherwise miss. For instance, using a short-period RSI plus a long-period RSI can help the model capture both short-term and longer-term momentum shifts.</p>
<p><strong>Customized Analysis</strong>
Your trading domain knowledge is invaluable. If you suspect that volume spikes matter more in certain regimesâ€”or that mean reversion patterns are better detected by certain oscillatorsâ€”feature engineering lets you align your inputs with your intuition.</p>
<p><strong>Noise Reduction & Stability</strong>
Smoothing raw data, filtering out outliers, or using rolling statistics can prevent the model from overreacting to random fluctuations. This is especially important when combining multiple indicators in PineScript.</p>
<p><strong>Iterative Exploration</strong>
There is rarely a â€œone-size-fits-allâ€ feature set. The markets evolve, and so might your trading strategy. Feature engineering provides a flexible framework to adapt, add, or remove features as you gather new evidence or change market focus.</p>
<p><strong>Multi-Method Strategies</strong>
Combining diverse indicator typesâ€”momentum, trend, volatility, mean reversionâ€”often leads to more robust modeling. For example, pairing RSI (momentum) with a WaveTrend oscillator (smoothed momentum) can give a balanced view of market oscillations.</p>
<h2 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="example-use-cases">Example Use Cases<a href="#example-use-cases" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to Example Use Cases" title="Direct link to Example Use Cases">â€‹</a></h2>
<h3 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="1-dual-length-rsi-for-multiple-market-regimes">1. Dual-Length RSI for Multiple Market Regimes<a href="#1-dual-length-rsi-for-multiple-market-regimes" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to 1. Dual-Length RSI for Multiple Market Regimes" title="Direct link to 1. Dual-Length RSI for Multiple Market Regimes">â€‹</a></h3>
<p><strong>Scenario</strong>: You want one RSI tuned to short-term swings and another capturing broader trends.
<strong>Implementation</strong>:</p>
<ul>
<li>Enable â€œRSIâ€ in two feature slots with different lengths (e.g., RSI(9) and RSI(14)).</li>
<li>Compare signals from short RSI to detect choppy market turnarounds, and longer RSI to capture more extended trends.</li>
</ul>
<h3 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="2-momentum--trend-strength-combination">2. Momentum + Trend-Strength Combination<a href="#2-momentum--trend-strength-combination" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to 2. Momentum + Trend-Strength Combination" title="Direct link to 2. Momentum + Trend-Strength Combination">â€‹</a></h3>
<p><strong>Scenario</strong>: You suspect that a momentum oscillator (like WaveTrend) plus a trend-strength measure (like ADX) will identify stronger breakouts.
<strong>Implementation</strong>:</p>
<ul>
<li>Assign WaveTrend to Feature 1 and ADX to Feature 2 in the Lorentzian Classification UI.</li>
<li>Ensure both are normalized so that ADXâ€™s higher scale doesnâ€™t overshadow WaveTrend values.</li>
<li>Look for synergy: WaveTrend spotting momentum changes while ADX confirms if the move has real trend strength.</li>
</ul>
<h3 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="3-mean-reversion--volatility-filter">3. Mean Reversion + Volatility Filter<a href="#3-mean-reversion--volatility-filter" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to 3. Mean Reversion + Volatility Filter" title="Direct link to 3. Mean Reversion + Volatility Filter">â€‹</a></h3>
<p><strong>Scenario</strong>: You primarily trade mean reversions but only when volatility is above a certain threshold.
<strong>Implementation</strong>:</p>
<ul>
<li>Use something like CCI or Bollinger-based data for your primary â€œmean reversionâ€ feature.</li>
<li>Add a volatility measure (such as ATR or a custom-coded volatility indicator) to Feature 2.</li>
<li>Enable normalization for both features. If volatility is low, the model can down-rank those data points in neighbor matching.</li>
</ul>
<h3 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="4-multi-timeframe-signals">4. Multi-Timeframe Signals<a href="#4-multi-timeframe-signals" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to 4. Multi-Timeframe Signals" title="Direct link to 4. Multi-Timeframe Signals">â€‹</a></h3>
<p><strong>Scenario</strong>: You scalp on a 5-minute chart but want confirmation from a daily trend.
<strong>Implementation</strong>:</p>
<ul>
<li>Load a daily ADX or daily RSI as a custom source in Feature 4 or 5.</li>
<li>Combine it with your intraday oscillator in Features 1â€“3.</li>
<li>Check if the higher-timeframe trend dimension helps filter out false positives on the lower timeframe.</li>
</ul>
<h3 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="5-custom-oscillator--doubling-up-for-emphasis">5. Custom Oscillator + Doubling-Up for Emphasis<a href="#5-custom-oscillator--doubling-up-for-emphasis" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to 5. Custom Oscillator + Doubling-Up for Emphasis" title="Direct link to 5. Custom Oscillator + Doubling-Up for Emphasis">â€‹</a></h3>
<p><strong>Scenario</strong>: You have a proprietary oscillator that strongly correlates with your market, and you want it to weigh more heavily in the classification.
<strong>Implementation</strong>:</p>
<ul>
<li>Map the proprietary oscillator as a custom feature.</li>
<li>Add the same feature again (with identical parameters) in another feature slot to double its influence.</li>
<li>Confirm both features are normalized to ensure balanced impact among the rest of the indicators.</li>
</ul>
<h2 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="the-iterative-approach">The Iterative Approach<a href="#the-iterative-approach" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to The Iterative Approach" title="Direct link to The Iterative Approach">â€‹</a></h2>
<p><strong>Start Small</strong>
Begin with one or two well-known indicators (e.g., RSI, WaveTrend). Verify that the Lorentzian Classification indicator produces stable, interpretable signals.</p>
<p><strong>Add Features Gradually</strong>
Introduce a single new featureâ€”like CCI, ADX, or a custom metricâ€”at a time. Observe changes in the modelâ€™s on-chart signals and the â€œTrade Statsâ€ section. Overhauling your feature set all at once makes it hard to pinpoint whatâ€™s helping or hurting.</p>
<p><strong>Check Normalization</strong>
If a newly added feature has a different range (for example, ADX can grow larger than RSI), make sure the â€œNormalizationâ€ option is enabled to avoid skewing the distance calculations. Otherwise, that feature might dominate or dilute the influence of other features.</p>
<p><strong>Evaluate Correlations</strong>
Export your feature data to CSV and analyze correlations in Python or any statistical tool. High correlation between features can be redundant. On the other hand, features with low correlation might add unique information.</p>
<p><strong>Backtest & Forward Test</strong>
Although Lorentzian Classification includes on-chart trade stats, it is <strong>not</strong> a substitute for a full TradingView backtest or a more advanced backtesting framework.</p>
<ul>
<li>Use the Strategy Tester or a â€œBacktest Adapterâ€ to get a realistic performance overview.</li>
<li>Look for consistent improvements in metrics you care about (e.g., fewer false signals, higher win rate, better risk-adjusted returns).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Document Everything</strong>
Jot down which features and parameter settings youâ€™ve triedâ€”along with how the signals changed. Feature engineering is often trial-and-error. Keeping records prevents repeated mistakes and accelerates learning.</p>
<h2 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="key-settings--tips">Key Settings & Tips<a href="#key-settings--tips" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to Key Settings & Tips" title="Direct link to Key Settings & Tips">â€‹</a></h2>
<p><strong>Number of Features (Feature Count)</strong>
Increasing the number of features (e.g., from 2 to 5 or more) can capture more complexityâ€”but can also increase the risk of overfitting or PineScript timeouts. Many traders find a sweet spot around 5â€“8 features, <strong>but</strong> always test performance thoroughly.</p>
<p><strong>Parameter A & Parameter B</strong>
Many indicators have adjustable look-back periods or smoothing parameters. Small changes in these can drastically affect model predictions. For example, try RSI(14) vs. RSI(9) to capture different market regimes.</p>
<p><strong>â€œDouble-Upâ€ for Weighting</strong>
If you suspect one feature is more crucial than others, you can simulate giving it extra â€œweightâ€ by using that feature multiple times with the same parameters. This approach can boost the featureâ€™s influence in the distance calculation.</p>
<p><strong>Normalization Checkboxes</strong>
Each feature can be normalized by checking the relevant box in the UI. This ensures all features contribute on a level playing field. Not normalizing a large-range feature (e.g., ADX) can inadvertently dominate the modelâ€™s decisions.</p>
<p><strong>Custom Features</strong>
The indicator allows you to load external data streams or proprietary indicators. Make sure they produce valid floating-point values (not booleans or strings). If the external data is unbounded (like some volatility metrics), consider enabling normalization.</p>
<p><strong>Performance & Timeouts</strong>
If computations become slow or you get PineScript timeouts, try reducing the number of features or the maximum bars back. Another trick is <strong>downsampling</strong>: skipping bars or training on fewer historical bars to speed up calculations.</p>
<h2 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="pitfalls-to-avoid">Pitfalls to Avoid<a href="#pitfalls-to-avoid" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to Pitfalls to Avoid" title="Direct link to Pitfalls to Avoid">â€‹</a></h2>
<p><strong>Feature Overload</strong>
More features do <strong>not</strong> always yield better results. Beyond a certain point, â€œcurse of dimensionalityâ€ can degrade accuracy and slow performance. Keep your feature set purposeful.</p>
<p><strong>Unbalanced Scales</strong>
Failing to normalize can allow high-range indicators (like ADX or unbounded CCI) to overshadow others.</p>
<p><strong>Redundant Indicators</strong>
Two highly correlated indicators (e.g., RSI and Stoch RSI with the same length) might not add unique value.</p>
<p><strong>Boolean or Categorical Series</strong>
Lorentzian Classification typically assumes float inputs. Passing a series of <code>1</code> and <code>0</code> can distort distance calculations. If you must encode a boolean, consider converting it to a fraction or smoothed float.</p>
<h2 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="key-takeaways">Key Takeaways<a href="#key-takeaways" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to Key Takeaways" title="Direct link to Key Takeaways">â€‹</a></h2>
<p>Align transforms with your hypothesis.<br>
<!-- -->Track performance rigorously.<br>
<!-- -->Refine continually.<br>
<!-- -->Know when to stop.</p>
<div class="settingHelp_drV6"><h4></h4><div class="defaultValue_KIb_">Default: <code>undefined</code></div><div class="purpose_A3Y6"><h5>Purpose</h5><p></p></div></div>
<h2 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="example-configurations">Example Configurations<a href="#example-configurations" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to Example Configurations" title="Direct link to Example Configurations">â€‹</a></h2>
<h3 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="high-precision-trend-following-configuration">High-Precision Trend Following Configuration:<a href="#high-precision-trend-following-configuration" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to High-Precision Trend Following Configuration:" title="Direct link to High-Precision Trend Following Configuration:">â€‹</a></h3>
<ul>
<li><strong>Number of Features:</strong> 5</li>
<li><strong>Feature 1:</strong> RSI (Parameter A: 14, Parameter B: 1) - <em>Reasoning: Standard RSI for momentum.</em></li>
<li><strong>Feature 2:</strong> WT (Parameter A: 10, Parameter B: 11) - <em>Reasoning: WaveTrend for smoothed momentum.</em></li>
<li><strong>Feature 3:</strong> ADX (Parameter A: 20, Parameter B: 2) - <em>Reasoning: ADX for trend strength confirmation.</em></li>
<li><strong>Feature 4:</strong> CCI (Parameter A: 20, Parameter B: 1) - <em>Reasoning: CCI for volatility-based momentum.</em></li>
<li><strong>Feature 5:</strong> RSI (Parameter A: 9, Parameter B: 1) - <em>Reasoning: Short-period RSI for capturing short-term swings, complementing longer-period RSI.</em></li>
<li><strong>Normalization:</strong> Enabled for all features - <em>Reasoning: Ensures balanced contribution from all features despite different scales.</em>
<em>This configuration is designed for users who prioritize high-precision trend following. It combines a diverse set of momentum, trend strength, and volatility indicators to create a robust feature set. The dual RSI feature allows the model to capture both short-term and long-term momentum, while ADX and CCI add trend and volatility context. Normalization is crucial to ensure that all features contribute equally to the model's predictions, preventing any single indicator from dominating the analysis.</em></li>
</ul>
<h3 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="custom-volume-based-strategy-configuration">Custom Volume-Based Strategy Configuration:<a href="#custom-volume-based-strategy-configuration" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to Custom Volume-Based Strategy Configuration:" title="Direct link to Custom Volume-Based Strategy Configuration:">â€‹</a></h3>
<ul>
<li><strong>Number of Features:</strong> 3</li>
<li><strong>Feature 1:</strong> Custom 1 (Volume Weighted MACD, Normalize: Enabled, Parameter A: 12, Parameter B: 26) - <em>Reasoning: Volume-weighted MACD to capture momentum confirmed by volume.</em></li>
<li><strong>Feature 2:</strong> Custom 2 (On Balance Volume, Normalize: Enabled, Parameter A: 14, Parameter B: 1) - <em>Reasoning: On Balance Volume to measure buying and selling pressure.</em></li>
<li><strong>Feature 3:</strong> ADX (Parameter A: 20, Parameter B: 2) - <em>Reasoning: ADX for trend strength confirmation, ensuring volume breakouts are trend-supported.</em></li>
<li><strong>All other features:</strong> Disabled - <em>Reasoning: Focuses the model on volume and trend strength, avoiding dilution from other feature types.</em>
<em>This configuration is tailored for users who believe volume is a critical factor in market movements. It integrates volume-based indicators with trend strength to identify volume-confirmed breakouts and avoid false signals. Volume Weighted MACD and On Balance Volume provide complementary perspectives on volume and momentum, while ADX ensures that trades are aligned with strong trends. Normalization is enabled for custom sources to balance their scale with ADX.</em></li>
</ul>
<h3 class="anchor anchorWithStickyNavbar_NHr2" id="low-latency-scalping-configuration">Low-Latency Scalping Configuration:<a href="#low-latency-scalping-configuration" class="hash-link" aria-label="Direct link to Low-Latency Scalping Configuration:" title="Direct link to Low-Latency Scalping Configuration:">â€‹</a></h3>
<ul>
<li><strong>Number of Features:</strong> 3</li>
<li><strong>Feature 1:</strong> RSI (Parameter A: 7, Parameter B: 1) - <em>Reasoning: Short-period RSI for quick momentum detection in scalping.</em></li>
<li><strong>Feature 2:</strong> WT (Parameter A: 5, Parameter B: 5) - <em>Reasoning: Short-period WaveTrend for fast, smoothed momentum signals.</em></li>
<li><strong>Feature 3:</strong> CCI (Parameter A: 10, Parameter B: 1) - <em>Reasoning: Short-period CCI for capturing short-term volatility swings.</em></li>
<li><strong>Max Bars Back:</strong> 1500 - <em>Reasoning: Reduces computational load and emphasizes recent price action relevant to scalping.</em></li>
<li><strong>Normalization:</strong> Enabled for all features - <em>Reasoning: Maintains balanced feature contribution despite different indicator scales.</em>
<em>This configuration is optimized for scalping strategies that require low latency and quick responses. It uses shorter lookback periods for RSI, WT, and CCI to increase responsiveness to intraday price movements. Reducing 'Max Bars Back' further minimizes computational load, ensuring the indicator remains fast and reactive. Normalization is enabled to maintain balanced feature contribution. This setup prioritizes speed and responsiveness over long-term trend analysis, making it suitable for fast-paced intraday trading.</em></li>
</ul></div></article><nav class="docusaurus-mt-lg pagination-nav" aria-label="Docs pages"><a class="pagination-nav__link pagination-nav__link--prev" href="/docs/indicators/lorentzian-classification/custom-sources"><div class="pagination-nav__sublabel">Previous</div><div class="pagination-nav__label">Custom Sources</div></a><a class="pagination-nav__link pagination-nav__link--next" href="/docs/indicators/lorentzian-classification/filters-settings"><div class="pagination-nav__sublabel">Next</div><div class="pagination-nav__label">Filters Settings</div></a></nav></div></div><div class="col col--3"><div class="tableOfContents_cdg3 thin-scrollbar theme-doc-toc-desktop"><ul class="table-of-contents table-of-contents__left-border"><li><a href="#interactive-settings-explorer" class="table-of-contents__link toc-highlight table-of-contents__link--active">Interactive Settings Explorer</a></li><li><a href="#why-feature-engineering-matters" class="table-of-contents__link toc-highlight">Why Feature Engineering Matters</a></li><li><a href="#example-use-cases" class="table-of-contents__link toc-highlight">Example Use Cases</a><ul><li><a href="#1-dual-length-rsi-for-multiple-market-regimes" class="table-of-contents__link toc-highlight">1.
